stem: A postpartum client, 24 hours after a vaginal delivery, reports heavy lochia with large clots and is saturating a perineal pad in 15 minutes. Which of the following findings require immediate nursing intervention?

rationale.correct: Boggy fundus. A boggy fundus indicates uterine atony, which is a primary cause of postpartum hemorrhage. Immediate intervention is required to prevent further blood loss.

mnemonic.fourTs: The Four Ts of Postpartum Hemorrhage: Tone (uterine atony), Trauma (lacerations, hematomas), Tissue (retained placental fragments), Thrombin (coagulation disorders).

rationale.incorrect:
Elevated blood pressure. While elevated blood pressure should be monitored, it is not the priority in the presence of heavy bleeding and suspected uterine atony.
Increased heart rate. An increased heart rate can be a compensatory mechanism for blood loss, but addressing the source of the bleeding (uterine atony) is the priority.
Client report of afterpains. Afterpains are normal postpartum contractions and are not the priority in this situation.

questionTrap.reason: Students may be distracted by the abnormal vital signs or the potential for afterpains, but the priority is to identify the cause of the hemorrhage.
questionTrap.commonMistake: Focusing on oxygenation or pain management before addressing the active bleeding.

clinicalPearls: Postpartum hemorrhage is defined as a cumulative blood loss of >1000 mL or bleeding associated with signs/symptoms of hypovolemia within 24 hours after birth, regardless of route of delivery.
The most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage is uterine atony.
Early recognition and prompt intervention are crucial in managing postpartum hemorrhage to prevent complications such as hypovolemic shock.

Atony is the failure of the uterus to contract adequately after delivery. Risk factors include: grand multiparity, multiple gestation, polyhydramnios, prolonged labor, use of oxytocin, and history of uterine atony.

itemContext.sbar:
10:15, RN calling from postpartum unit regarding Ms. Smith, DOB 03/04/1996. 24 hours post-spontaneous vaginal delivery. G1P1, no complications during pregnancy. 

S: Patient reports increased vaginal bleeding with large clots. States, "I'm soaking through a pad every 15 minutes."

B: Unremarkable medical history. Prenatal vitamins discontinued at delivery. No known allergies.

A: Fundus is boggy and difficult to locate. Lochia is heavy, with large clots noted. Perineal pad saturated in the last 15 minutes. Vital signs: HR 110, BP 130/80, RR 20, SpO2 98% on room air.

R: I recommend immediate assessment of uterine tone and ongoing vital sign monitoring. Consider fundal massage and notify provider for potential interventions such as uterotonic medications.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content: 10:10 HR: 110 bpm BP: 130/80 mmHg RR: 20 breaths/min SpO2: 98% on room air Temperature: 37.0°C (98.6°F)

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: 09:00 Hemoglobin: 12.0 g/dL Hematocrit: 36% Platelets: 250,000/μL Coagulation studies: Within normal limits

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content: General: Alert and oriented, but appears anxious. Cardiovascular: Tachycardia noted, no murmurs. Respiratory: Clear and equal breath sounds bilaterally. Abdomen: Fundus boggy and difficult to locate. Moderate tenderness upon palpation. Genitourinary: Heavy lochia with large clots. Perineal pad saturated in 15 minutes. No hematoma noted.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content: Priority Problem: Risk for postpartum hemorrhage related to uterine atony. Goal: Client will maintain stable vital signs and minimal vaginal bleeding. Interventions: -Assess fundal tone and lochia every 15 minutes. -Massage fundus as needed to maintain firmness. -Monitor vital signs closely. -Administer uterotonic medications as prescribed. -Monitor for signs and symptoms of hypovolemic shock.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Oxytocin 20 units in 1000 mL Lactated Ringers - infusing at 125 mL/hr
Ibuprofen 600 mg PO every 6 hours PRN for pain
